sp.p: The man is dyingâ€”James quick, fetch a doctor hereâ€”quick ! (calls L D.)

sp.speaker: Adolphe.
sp.p: I'm trickedâ€”trappedâ€”I lose all.

div.stage: Re-enter LIZZIE, BOBBIN, BATTER, MRS. DACRE, and Grace, L D.

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: Oh, look at Froggy now, he's turning blue.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: (to Mrs. Dacre) Mother, the power of retribution is in this, that man has met his doom at the hands of his villainous accomplice,â€”he is poisoned.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Poisoned!

sp.speaker: Adolphe.
sp.p: Oh, save me, I am not fit to die ; see de old man, I kill him, and now he bid me follow him ; keep him off, keep him off, I must not die, I cannot, he have -.me nowâ€”let me goâ€”let me go, offâ€”off ! (falls dead.)

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: . (stooping over him) The man is dead!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Dead! (Tableau of surprise.)

div.head: SCENE FIRST.â€”Drawing-room, as before.
div.stage: Reginald. and MRS. DACRE seated at table.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: We are now rid of our chief enemy; the villain who would have brought me down to his own level, has been laid low himself. You surely do not now believe my father met his death at my hands ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. D.
sp.p: I do not, Reginald, for my eyes are opened to the villany of that man.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Mathew Barkin would see you, sir.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: Show him in. Every man has his price; I must see what this man values himself at.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Good day, ma'amâ€”good day, sir. I suppose you can guess what I've called about ?

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: A certain document, I suppose ?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Right you are.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: You come to make terms as to giving it up ?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Right you are again ; are you willing to deal ?

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: Perfectly ; name your price.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I want to get away from this country. I shall settle down in a foreign land, become respectable, live on the fruits of my industry, and turn religious.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: Well, you will not be the first knave who has done this to suit his purpose. Come to the point.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: If you please.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: What sum do you require for the will ?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: It's as good as giving it to youâ€” five hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: . (aside) It's less than half what I expected.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: (aside) He bites!

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: (to Mrs. Dacre) Shall we not rid ourselves of this man, obtain the will, and then set him at defiance?

sp.speaker: Mrs. D.
sp.p: Yes, I will fetch the money for you. (exit, R. D.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: You do wisely in quitting the country, for villain as that man was, you really murdered him.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Nobody knows that but you, and if I thought there was danger of being bowled out, I would swear you set me on to do it, and the reason you had for putting the Frenchman out of the way. I'm no hypocrite, but an honest, fair-dealing man.

div.stage: Re-enter Mrs. DACRE, with notes, R.

sp.speaker: Mrs. D.
sp.p: There is the money, now let this business be settled for ever.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: Come, the will ?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Now do you really think I am such a fool ? why I might lose it, or some dishonest persons might take advantage of me and steal it.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: How am I to get it then ?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You'll have to come with me to Field-lane, contagious to Mutton-hill.

sp.speaker: Mrs. D.
sp.p: No, Reginald, don't go.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Oh, very well, if it's not worth fetching it's not worth having, (going.)

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: Stay! (to her) Don't be alarmed, you see it is necessary that I should go.

sp.speaker: Mrs. D.
sp.p: But had you not better take some one with you.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: How can I, without their knowing what I wish to be kept secret ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. D.
sp.p: True, true.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Now then, if you're coming, 'cause my time's valuable, I've got two dog-fights and a rat-killing match to come on.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: Good-bye for the present; don't fear for me I know how how to take care of myself. I am ready.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Come along, then.

sp.speaker: Mrs. D.
sp.p: M. D. I can do nothing, but hope for his safety and pray for his return.

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: Beg pardon, is Mr. Reginald here ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. D.
sp.p: He has just left the house, I wonder you didn't meet him.

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: I wanted to meet him, because I've seen a man watching the house, who's no good; and mischief follows wherever he goes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. D.
sp.p: Do you mean a man called Mathew Barkin ?

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: That's the individual.

sp.speaker: Mrs. D.
sp.p: Reginald has just left the house with him.

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: (aside) And has he been so green ? (aloud) He hasn't any money with him I hope ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. D.
sp.p: Yes, a considerable sum; why do you ask ?

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: Oh, nothing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. D.
sp.p: I should like to confide in some one. Is Mr. Wharton in the house ?

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: No, but his sister and Miss Lizzie are, they expect him in every minute.

sp.speaker: Mrs. D.
sp.p: Will you ask him, when he arrives, to see me in my room ?

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. D.
sp.p: Thank you. (exit, R.D.

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: A considerable sum of money with him, and in company of Mathew Barkinâ€”it's like a mouse going into a trap after a bit of toasted cheese. I know what I'll do ; I have two old suits of clothes at my lodgings, get Bobbin and Lizzie to put them on, and make them go and watch the little affairâ€”it wouldn't do for me to go, having been in the forceâ€”and got them to meet me at the corner of Chizzleman-street, Finsbury-square. (exit at door, L.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You're acting on the square, arn't you? You're not playing a double game ?

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Why, you've not set anybody to watch meâ€”because if that's the case, we'll drop the business here.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: You've no cause for alarm, I'm alone in this affairâ€”and ready to fulfil my promise, the moment I gain possession of the paper you hold. I await your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: No, I await yours. Come with me, and you will get what I have in store for you.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: The sooner the better. (exeunt, R.

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p:
There they go. Where are the girls I wonder ? They ought to have turned themselves into boys by this
time. I hope no dishonest persons has broken into my lodgings and stolen the ragged clothes and birch-brooms. Why, here's a lot of my acquaintanceâ€”the flower-makers, I declare! Here's Anne Brown, Mary Green, Carry White, Bella Brill, and the rest of 'em. I can't cut the girls, though I am a gentleman ; no, no, condescension to our inferiors proves us to be superiors.

sp.speaker: Carry.
sp.p: It is!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: It isn't!

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: It must be!

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: It's his very face!

sp.speaker: Carry.
sp.p: I'm sure it's Batter.

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: Batter it is, my flower, but for the future perhaps you will call me Mr. Batter, for my future better half has taken me out of the division.

sp.speaker: All the Girls.
sp.p: What Bobbin,â€”ah, tell us all about her.

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: Not too close, if Bobbin was to see you, Bobbin mightn't like it; Bobbin had a brother who wrote home to say he was deadâ€”at least somebody else did, but Bobbin's brother came back purposely to say he wasn't dead but was alive and rich.

sp.speaker: All the Girls.
sp.p: Rich ?

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: Rich as a magogâ€”a nabob I meanâ€”and Bobbin now is rich as a nabobess.

sp.speaker: Girls.
sp.p: And Lizzie Lyle, what of her ?

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: Bobbin has taken Lizzie Lyle by the hand and set her on her legs and me too, I'm on my legs, they're now my own property and no longer in the pay of Government.

sp.speaker: Girls.
sp.p: We must see Lizzie ! we must see Bobbin!

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: (aside) Here they come, they'll see 'em sooner than they expect. But I hope they won't know 'em. Enter BOBBIN and LIZZIE, disguised as crossing-sweepers, L. Excuse me, my dears, but I've an appointment with these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Girls.
sp.p: Gentlemen, ha ! ha!

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: And so they are gentlemen, young noblemen in disguise, that I'm going to show a little London life !

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: Why here are the girls we used to work with.

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: (aside to them) Keep it up, talk to 'em in that sort of way girls likeâ€”you know what I mean ?

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p:
(crosses to them) How are you my dears, how's all your sweethearts ? when are you going to name the
happy day, and when are they going to buy the ring, eh ? My flowers of flower-makers

sp.speaker: Lizzie.
sp.p: Good evening, my dears, I hope you find business good in all it's sprigs and branches.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Keep off you ragged little fellow, I don't believe you're any more a nobleman than I am. Come along girls, don't stand talking to him. (exit L

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Go home and tell your mother to mend your clothes. (exit L.

sp.speaker: Carry.
sp.p: And give you a penny to go to the baths and washhouses in Golden-lane. (exit L.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: And mind you're well off for soap. (exit l.

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: Well, now, doesn't that prove they don't know you.

sp.speaker: Lizzie.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Batter, I'm so frightened.

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: Of course you are, how do you feel, Bobbin ?

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: I don't know, I'll tell you when it's all over. How are we to begin ?

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: I'll tell you all as we go along. Now, girls, be firm, act like men although you're women.

sp.speaker: Lizzie.
sp.p: I'll try ; we can do much for those we love.

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: Miss Bobbin, can you do much for those you love?

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: Who are they ?

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: Who are they, ain't they me ?

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: Lor so they are ! then I will do muchâ€”a good deal of much, for you, for Lizzie, for Mr. Reginald, and for myself.

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: Come along, then, and learn your lessons as you go. (exeunt, R.

div.head: SCENE THIRD.
div.stage: A wall eight feet high across stage. Common lodging-houses R. and L., on which are written, "Lodgings for travellers." The scene presents an alley, door in wall C, is unlocked.
Enter MAT and REGINALD, at door, MAT locks door.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Welcome to the neighbourhood of Field-lane, Mr. Dacre ; a beautiful saloobrious bone biling neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: That's of little consequence, as I don't mean to stay long in itâ€”now to business.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: By all means, you've the money, of course ?

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: When you've the will ready.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll fetch it (aside) and give the office to my pals.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: A disreputable looking place, nothing but my anxiety to possess that will could have induced me to venture here ; but the place seems quiet enough, so what need I fear!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Here's the will.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: And here's the money.

div.stage: Enter several ROUGH MEN, from house, R.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Is the money in notes ?

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I wish you had brought gold, but I suppose I must pocket the affront. Here's the will.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: And here's the money, (offers notes â€”MAT snatches them) Ah, villain ! is it so? (the Men seize him) Let me go rascalsâ€”let me go!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Let you go ! Knowing what you do of me ? when your ends are gained by the destruction of the will, you'd split on me for the murder of the Frenchman!

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: No, I will be silent.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll take precious good care you are. Open, the trap that leads to the vaults; (the Men raise trap) now bundle him down.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: Villains ! would you murder me ?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: If you kick up a row we will.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: Set me at liberty, give me the will, and you shall have double the amount you have taken from me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You don't happen to have it about you, I suppose ?

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: No, but it can be sent for.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll consider and let you know. Down with him.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: Rascal, thief, murderer! (they force him down.)

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Break his infernal neck if he won't go quietly. (gives money to MEN) Go down to the "Pig" and have what you like.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Thank you, Matâ€”thankee. (Mat unlocks doors.â€” Men exit â€”he locks door again, puts key in pocket) Now all's smooth and comfortable, I'll have a pipe and look at the flimsies, (lights pipeâ€”looks over notes) One, two, three, fourâ€”fiveâ€”hundred-pun notesâ€”quite correct. How I does admire coves who keep their word. (Knock heard C.) Who's that?

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: (outside) A friend.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I ain't got none; they was all hung years ago. I want the pass-word before I let you inâ€”do you know it?

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: Plant and pigeon.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: What do you say ?

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: Plant and pigeon.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: That's good Englishâ€”come in. (unlocks C. door.)
Enter BOBBIN and LIZZIE, C. Hollo, you're fresh 'uns.

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: Yes, guv'nor, we've not long taken to the honest trade of prigging, but was told if there ever was a man who could finish the eddication of two novices in the line, that gemman was the respected Mr. Mathew Barkin.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: They does me proud whoever it wasâ€”has I the honour of knowing the party ?

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: You has. Vere recommended by Jack Flanagan, of Seven Dialsâ€”he would have written to you, only he says that he knows as you knows that he can't write.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: No, he can'tâ€”his eddication was neglected in early lifeâ€”he can only make his mark, and has lived on the cross ever since; but he's a nice man.

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: Oh, very; nothing escapes either his obserwation or his fingers.

sp.speaker: Lizzie.
sp.p: (aside) I see nothing of Reginaldâ€”can he be a prisoner here ?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Well, I'll see what I can make of you in the morning.

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: (aside) Catch me staying till then! (aloud) Then I suppose I and my mate can lodge here to-night?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Oh, yes; but I shall have to part you and just ax you separately about certain things when I get you alone.

sp.speaker: Lizzie.
sp.p: (aside) Does he suspect anything?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: (points R. house) You'll go in there and snoozeâ€” you'll see a bed in the taproomâ€”it's well aired, for my dog sleeps in it all day. (to Lizzie) You'll sleep yonderâ€” there's a clean truss of straw in the corner ; make it nicely, and don't ruffle the feathers too much, 'cause you'll have a bed-fellowâ€”Dick Scraggs, the fighting chummy.

sp.speaker: Lizzie.
sp.p: If my courage should fail among these ruffians !

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: (aside) If we're found out, we're in for it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Get inâ€”you'll be in the way out here.

sp.speaker: Lizzie.
sp.p: But I thought â€”â€”

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Then you needn'tâ€”I'll think for you.

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: But I've somemut to say to him.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
I'll say it for you. If I find there is anything
wrongâ€”war hawks ! my chickens, to roost with you. (to Lizzie) You firstâ€”in with you.

sp.speaker: Lizzie.
sp.p: Goodnightâ€”I'm going; good night, Bob.

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: Good night, Jimmy.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Bless my eyesâ€”how complimentary we is. What boarding-school was you brought up in, I wonder ? I believe I said be off.

sp.speaker: Lizzie.
sp.p: I'm going, sir, (aside) and perhaps to my destruction ! (exit into house, L.

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: Oh, myâ€”isn't things beginning to look serious !

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Now, then, that's your way.

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: I never felt in a worse one! Oh, there's a policeman looking over the wall!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: There is ? (Bobbin hides behind house, Mat climbs up and looks over wall) None of your lies ! I see nobody. I shall owe you one, young 'un ! (Mat thinks she has gone in, locks door) You'll not come out again for some time!

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: (aside) I'm not in yet!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Perhaps I'm too fast! The police may be watching me ; I had better leave here while I'm safeâ€”this will will be a fortune to me. (takes will from pocket) As long as I've this I can draw money from the Dacre family! Mr. Reginald's safe in my clutches !

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: (aside) Oh, he is, eh?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: This is his pocket-bookâ€”well lined with bank notes.

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: (aside) Indeed ! That's worth knowing. .

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I might live very comfortably in France.

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: If I allow you to take French leave !

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: What shall I do? I'll just have half a pint and think it over! (lights pipe, puts will and pocket-book into R. pocket.)

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: (aside) There goes the moneyâ€”and the will that's worth the money ! (he puts the keys in the other pocket) Oh, if I dared! I'll try to get the keys first and set Lizzie at liberty. They say where there's a will there's a way ! (takes keys out of his pocket â€” opens the house door quietly, and goes in.)

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Yes, I'll look to myself! The game's in my own handsâ€”I'll be off and twig things from afarâ€”I'm off while I am safe! (goes to door, misses keys) Have I dropped them, or have I taken them from my pocket ? Perhaps I have been locked in to be nailedâ€”here goes over the wall. (begins to climb wall.)

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: Open the door, quick! (Lizzie opens door in wall â€”sees Mat climbing wall) Ah, there ho goes, and takes his booty with himâ€”I'll have a try for it. (runs up, reaches the tails of Mat's coat, pulls away desperately at them, the tails come away, she utters a cry of triumphâ€” makes for door, Mat runs after himâ€” Lizzie gets crowbar and knocks Mat down, and exit through door, locking it after her.)

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Never mind, I'll have my revenge on the fellow in the vault, (opens trap) Come up, I want a word with you. (Reginald comes up.)

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: Now, villain, name your price.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I shan't, till I make sure. I've lost one great hold upon youâ€”the will; and I don't part with you till it answers my purpose, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: You've lost the will ?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Yes, some of your friends in disguise has done that for me. You're my last and only card, and I'll play you well before I let you loose.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: What do you require ?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: The money you brought me, the five hundred pounds, has slipped through my fingersâ€”now I must have double that sum.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: How can I procure it while you keep me a prisoner here ? Set me free, and I'll get it for you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Ah, ah! I dare sayâ€”wouldn't you like it? You'd go to the nearest police-station, and have me nabbed. No, you must write me a cheque here. I'll find pens, ink and paper, and when I get the cheque, and get it changed into gold, you shall be free.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: But even if I wrote the cheque for you, how do I know you'd ever return when you've got the money ?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Oh, what a bad, suspicious world, this is ! Surely my word of honour ought to be enough for any gentleman.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: Shall I risk it ? it's worth the trial; he has no longer the will that renders me a beggar. I agree. Give me pen, ink and paper. (Mat fetches pen, ink and paper from house, R.)

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Now go to work.

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: Remember your promise.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Oh, honour bright and shining! (aside) on a foggy night. (Reginald writes on chair)

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: (gives paper) There !

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: What a beautiful hand you do write, to be sure !

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: Now, be quick, release me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: M. Oh, oh, what a fool I should be !

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
To look to myself! What! do you think I am
such a fool as to set the man free who could accuse me of the murder of his father? Don't I know you would never rest till I was scragged? I won't be that while I have the means to help it! (draws knife) I hold the knife in my right hand, and cheque in my left! It gives me the means of life . You know too muchâ€”and this must give you death ! Die ! (raises knife to strike.)

div.stage: Batter rushes on through C. door.

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: No. Batter to the rescueâ€”die yourself !

div.stage: Enter BOBBIN, LIZZIE, and MRS. DACRE.

sp.speaker: Batter.
sp.p: He's safeâ€”he's well!

sp.speaker: Reginald.
sp.p: Yes, I'm free from peril and unharmed! This is the kind friend who saved my life.

sp.speaker: Bobbin.
sp.p: And I'll save your fortuneâ€”there's the will! (tears it) Look Mr. Barkins, we need fear your bark no more, and the Flower Makers are in full bloom after all!
